meta.title: Under the Microscope: A Brief History of Microscopy
meta.author: William J Croft
meta.publisher: World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte. Ltd.

parts.title: History and Evolution of Microscopy
parts.body: The foreword of "Under the Microscope" explores the history of humanity's fascination with the "small world", from early magnifying lenses to modern sophisticated techniques. The book covers the milestones in microscopy, including van Leeuwenhoek's high-resolution microscopes and the evolution of optical and electron microscopes, eventually leading to modern scanning probe microscopy. It places significant emphasis on the increasing magnification and measurement units such as microns and nanometers used in today's high-tech microscopes, setting a context for the atomic-scale imaging.

parts.title: Pioneers of Early Microscopy: Hooke and Leeuwenhoek
parts.body: Robert Hooke (1635-1703) was a pivotal figure in early microscopy. Known for the book "Micrographia," he coined the term "cells" after observing the structure of cork. Despite preferring compound microscopes, he acknowledged the clarity of single lens instruments. Hooke made major contributions, including Hooke's Law of elasticity and early theories regarding the wave nature of light. Another significant contributor was Antony van Leeuwenhoek, a Dutch draper (1632-1723). Despite no formal education, he ground microscope lenses and made groundbreaking biological observations. Leeuwenhoek discovered bacteria, sperm cells, and blood cells, contributing immensely to the field. Notably, he built over 500 microscopes and preferred single lens designs, contrary to Hooke's views. In his interactions, Leeuwenhoek was known for his meticulous nature and maintained a strong relationship with the Royal Society in London. His diverse work experience included roles such as surveyor and wine assayer. Through dedication, he raised scientific awareness and his discoveries caught the attention of many contemporary scientists. Known for meticulous methods, his exact surname's pronunciation remains a point of historic curiosity.

parts.title: Historical Foundations of Microscopy and Optics
parts.body:
Summary of Key Points: Early Exploration of Light and Optics

The chapter highlights the historical development of microscopy, beginning with the Ancient Greeks. It notes early observations such as Aristophanes' mention of glass globules in Athens and Euclid's foundational work in optics, around 300 B.C.. These figures laid the groundwork for understanding light as a straight line and the phenomenon of refraction, where light bends upon entering different media. Important concepts like refraction are explained with visual aids: a stick appearing bent in water, and soldiers changing direction on uneven terrain, illustrating light's behavior as it travels through different densities. The transition from low- to high-density media (e.g., air to glass) further explains light bending towards the surface. Curved surfaces on glass lead to lens formation, demonstrating early understandings of optics and magnification. The discovery of a plano-convex lens at Nimrod signifies early lens use, presumed to date back to the 700s B.C., though initially thought to be more decorative than functional. By the first century A.D., individuals like Seneca discussed magnification through water globes. Innovations like spectacles in 1280 Florence amplified still-limited but intriguing optical knowledge, spreading quickly across the world while laying the foundations for more advanced studies.

parts.title: Understanding Crystals' Symmetry and Structure
parts.body: Crystals are solid structures with periodically arranged atoms, contrasting with glasses and liquids where atoms are randomly arranged. The periodicity in crystals gives them unique properties. A key concept is the "law of constancy of interfacial angles" discovered by Nicolaus Steno in 1669, stating that angles between similar crystal faces are constant across crystals of the same material. This finding led to understanding that crystal properties result from their internal structure. Symmetry plays a crucial role in classifying crystals, which can be understood through symmetry operations like rotations and mirrors. This helps organize the structure into six crystal systems: cubic, tetragonal, hexagonal, orthorhombic, monoclinic, and triclinic, each defined by the axes and angles of their crystal structure. Symmetry in crystals is determined by axes, planes, and a center of symmetry. Some crystals have 2-fold or 3-fold symmetry axes, and others like cubes display planes of symmetry acting like mirrors. A third type of symmetry is the center of symmetry, where for every feature, a copy is found at an equal distance on the opposite side. With a mix of these elements, crystals fall into 32 point groups, describing the morphology of crystals. However, these point groups don't fully capture the atomic arrangements in a crystal. Historically, naturalists believed crystals were made of basic building blocks, a theory supported by Abbe Rene Just Haiiy despite his inability to see these blocks with his microscopes. The repetition of the smallest structural unit fits into one of 14 Bravais lattices that describe the crystal's spatial arrangement, pre-dating von Laue's demonstration by over half a century. Understanding these concepts aids in applying polarizing microscopes, which reveal crystal properties by exploiting these symmetries using polarized light. For example, features like anisotropy or isotropy relate to how light interacts differently with crystals of varying symmetry. Early scientists who contributed to this field often combined tools like Nicol prisms, Canada balsam, and thin sections for studying rocks and crystals. With advancements in polarizing techniques, these methods now significantly enhance mineralogical, geological, and chemical study, informing practical applications in scientific research today.

parts.title: Polarized Light and Crystal Properties Overview
parts.body:
Polarized Light and Crystal Properties

In crystals, directional and value properties can be represented by vector surfaces. For example, in cubic crystals, thermal expansion appears isotropic, forming a sphere. However, in lower symmetry crystals like hexagonal or tetragonal, expansion forms a revolution ellipsoid. The optical properties, such as the velocity of light in a crystal, have vector surfaces like a sphere in cubic crystals, making them optically isotropic. Non-cubic crystals split light into two polarized rays — the ordinary ray (spherical vector surface) and the extraordinary ray (ellipsoid vector surface).

parts.title: Reflected Light Microscopy Highlights
parts.body:
Summary Chunk

Light Microscopy's history is filled with explorations into both transparent and opaque materials. While biological materials were initially more revealing, metals posed challenges due to their surface-level observations. In 1664, Henry Power documented metal surfaces, noting irregularities and vitrification of sparks, while Robert Hooke delved into this phenomenon in his famous "Micrographia" work. Hooke's compound microscope observations nurtured the development of metal study, although his metallurgical insights were limited to external features like scratches on a razor.

Metallurgical Advances

Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, known for his exploration of microscopic world, contributed to metals' study by identifying crystalline structures in the 1700s. Later, Henry Clifton Sorby, in 1850, advanced metal microscopy. Despite limited initial awareness, Sorby refined etching techniques and identified microstructures in steel, laying foundational metallurgical principles. His polishing and magnification methods were novel, serving as a lens into metal's micro-world. Sorby's microscope advancements contributed significantly to metallurgy, underpinning modern techniques.

Reflected Light and Scientific Developments

Through advances like R. Beck's reflector and Lieberkuhn’s mirror, greatly improved microscopy of opaque structures emerged. Sorby’s use of reflected light techniques distinguished textures and compositions, critical for studying metals like iron and steel. As science progressed, tools like electron-probe micro-analyzers provided refined ways to analyze opaque minerals, aligned with observed optical properties like brightness and hardness. This led to broader applications in Materials Science and Forensic Science, revealing the depth and complexity of the microstructures in metallurgical and other scientific fields.

parts.title: Beginnings of Electron Microscopy
parts.body: Electron microscopy has many contributors, with Max Knoll and Ernst Ruska making notable progress in 1931. They built a magnetic lens microscope, leading to advancements in electron microscope development. Günther Rüdenberg filed a patent for the electron microscope using multiple lenses the same year. The electron microscope's capability to see below atomic levels stems from electrons' small size compared to atoms, with techniques like Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) enhancing this ability. Electron guns and magnetic lenses form the core of the electron microscope, which captures images through fluorescent materials.

parts.title: Electron Diffraction and its Historical Development
parts.body: Electron diffraction is a powerful method used in electron microscopes to study the properties and structure of crystals. It builds upon Max von Laue's discovery of X-ray diffraction in 1912, showing that crystals can diffract X-rays and electrons into a periodic pattern, helping identify materials and their characteristics. In 1912, von Laue received a Nobel Prize for his work, which was further simplified by W.H. Bragg using Bragg's Law, allowing for the precise calculation of crystal structure based on the diffraction pattern.

parts.title: Chemical Composition Analysis via Microscopy Techniques
parts.body: Optical Microscopy uses polarized light for analyzing chemical composition of small samples, like in forensic or materials science. This technique, once widespread, is becoming obsolete due to the rise of instruments like the Electron Probe Microanalyser (EPMA), which enable precise analysis at higher costs. Unfortunately, optical methods are no longer commonly taught in universities, except in certain institutes like the McCrone Institute of Chicago. X-Rays and Electrons: The basics of the X-Ray process began with Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen's discovery, leading to the identification of different radiation types like K and L by Barkla. Later, the diffraction works by Max von Laue, and significant contributions by W. H. Bragg, and his son, confirmed the periodic nature of atoms and led to the development of X-ray spectrographs for material analysis. Henry Moseley revolutionized understanding atomic numbers through his X-ray spectrometry work with elements. Early X-ray Discoveries: Moseley's studies proved the periodic table's completeness and helped predict new elements. His pioneering work was cut short due to his early death in World War I. EPMA Development: Raymond Castaing developed the first microprobe for chemical analysis by modifying an electron microscope. Castaing detailed how localized analysis was possible by focusing an electron beam and measuring secondary X-rays. Despite its age, this technique strikes a balance between cost and efficacy for detailed compositional analysis.

parts.title: Atomic-Level Microscopic Techniques in Modern Studies
parts.body:
Quantum Microscopy and Molecule Imaging

The Scannning Probe Microscopes (SPM), including the Scanning Tunneling Microscope (STM), revolutionized microscopy by allowing visualization at an atomic level. The STM achieves this through an atomically sharp probe and quantum tunneling, overcoming limitations of traditional microscopes. Several issues such as vibration isolation, probe sharpening, and precise scanning movements were ingeniously addressed, which allowed visualization of the atomic arrangement on surfaces.

Atomic Force and New Measurement Modes

The Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) emerged as a derivative of the STM, enabling study of non-conductive surfaces. AFM uses an ultra-sharp tip to scan the surface topography and operates in contact or tapping modes. It's employed in varied environments including liquid, making it useful for biological samples. Besides topography, AFM supports techniques like Lateral Force Microscopy or Chemical Force Microscopy, which investigate frictional forces and molecular interactions.

Biofilms and Advanced Imaging Techniques

Confocal Microscopy solved the limitations of scattering by employing a confocal setup for better depth resolution, revealing structures like biofilms in detail. It aids in studies like drug effect on biofilms related to infections and implants. With rising demand for compact circuits, the use of microscopes for imaging and manipulating molecules anchors the advancement toward nanotechnology, where precision control at the molecular level intersects both microscopy and materials science.

parts.title: Acoustic Microscopy and Ultrasonic Imaging
parts.body: Acoustic Microscopy is a technology that uses sound waves to produce images with microscopic resolutions. Initially pioneered by Sergei Y. Sokolov in the 1920s, acoustic waves were explored for detecting flaws in metals due to their ability to penetrate materials opaque to light. Later advancements allowed these waves to be used in a reflective microscopy setting. Scanning acoustic microscopes (SAMs) have developed to provide high-resolution imaging and detect internal defects in various materials, including biological tissues and opaque materials. This ultrasonic technique involves sending a pulsed sound wave that reflects back, providing details about contrast in density changes within the examined materials. Two primary advantages of acoustic microscopy are its ability to examine opaque materials and produce contrast based on mechanical properties. Practical uses extend to medical imaging, non-destructive testing, and fetal examinations, showcasing changes in tissue density with high contrasts similar to or exceeding those of X-rays. As the technology advanced, SAMs evolved from a transmission mode to a reflection mode focusing on resolving issues of lens alignment. Most modern SAMs use surface waves to image features beneath opaque surfaces. These devices have become vital for analyzing optically opaque materials and applications like quality control in integrated circuit manufacture. Acoustic microscopes provide non-destructive inspection, examining features such as surface cracks, defects, and boundaries, bridging high resolution acoustic methods with conventional testing.
